choices.text: IPV is typically administered via the subcutaneous route.
IPV is usually given in a 0.1 ml dose via the intramuscular route.
IPV is typically given at 6 and 14 weeks of age
IPV cannot be co-administered with other vaccines due to increased risk of VAPP.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child presents to the clinic for routine vaccinations. The parents are concerned about the risks associated with the polio vaccine and inquire about the different types available. You explain the benefits and risks of both the inactivated polio vaccine (IPV) and the oral polio vaccine (OPV). Which of the following statements is correct regarding the administration of IPV?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) IPV is typically given at 6 and 14 weeks of age

 

Option C:

 

  • WHO states that two fractional dose IPV (0.1 ml each) administered via the intradermal (ID) route offer higher immunogenicity compared to one full intramuscular (IM) dose of IPV (0.5 ml).
  •  fIPV is safe, effective and more immunogenic, can be given alone, or at the same time as any other vaccine and also help to “boost” mucosal immunity.
  •  It is now introduced in the routine immunization programmes.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. IPV is not administered via the subcutaneous route; it is given intramuscularly.

 

Option B. The dose of IPV given intramuscularly is 0.5 ml, not 0.1 ml.

 

Option D. IPV can be co-administered with other vaccines, and there is no increased risk of VAPP because IPV is an inactivated vaccine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Under Routine immunization - (NEW National Immunization Schedule (NIS) 2023-24) fIPV is given intradermally at 6 weeks, 14 weeks and 9 months (3 doses) 

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Med Microbiology 1/e p479, 2/e p494-495

questions.text: In a community health center, a 3-year-old child is brought in by his parents. They recently moved from a country where polio is still endemic. The child had received an oral polio vaccine about two months ago. He now presents with acute onset of fever and asymmetric flaccid paralysis of his left leg. There is no sensory loss, and the parents report that the child was previously healthy. Which of the following is the most likely time frame in which vaccine-associated polio can manifest after vaccination?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 4-30 days 

 

Explanation:

 

Vaccine-associated paralytic poliomyelitis (VAPP) typically manifests within 4 to 30 days after receiving the oral polio vaccine. This time frame accounts for the incubation period of the vaccine virus and its potential mutation into a neurovirulent form. The child's presentation of asymmetric flaccid paralysis within this time frame is consistent with VAPP.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vaccine associated paralytic poliomyelitis (VAPP): Develop Paralytic Polio after 4-30 days (Average 7-14 days) of administration of OPV.

 

Poliomyelitis among Contacts of OPV: Develop within 7-60 days after exposure to recent OPV-recipient.

 

Ref: Polio Vaccines/WHO, ApurbaSastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p479, 2/e p495

choices.text: Detection of the poliovirus in the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF)
Detection of poliovirus antibodies in serum
Isolation of the poliovirus from stool specimens

questions.text: A health worker in a polio surveillance program is evaluating a case of acute flaccid paralysis (AFP) in a child. To confirm the diagnosis of polio, which of the following is the most reliable and standard method of diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C). Isolation of the poliovirus from stool specimens

 

Option C:

 

The gold standard for the diagnosis of poliomyelitis is the isolation of the poliovirus from stool specimens. This method is preferred due to the virus's fecal-oral route of transmission and the prolonged shedding of the virus in the stool of infected individuals.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. The poliovirus is rarely detected in the CSF, which makes it an unreliable method for confirming polio.

 

Option B. Serological tests can indicate a past infection or immunization but are not definitive for acute infection.

 

Option D. EMG can show findings suggestive of polio but is not diagnostic; the virus must be isolated for confirmation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The isolation of the poliovirus from stool specimens is the standard diagnostic method for poliomyelitis, particularly in the context of acute flaccid paralysis surveillance.

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p477, 2/e p496, Park 23/e p203-9, 24/e p218

questions.text: A public health official is reviewing data from a recent outbreak of poliomyelitis in a region where vaccine-derived poliovirus has been identified. Which of the following types of vaccine-derived poliovirus is least likely to be responsible for such an outbreak?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Mutant vaccine-derived poliovirus (mVDPV)

 

Option D:

 

The term "mutant vaccine-derived poliovirus (mVDPV)" is not a recognized category of vaccine-derived polioviruses. 

 

The VDPV categories includes circulating vaccine-derived poliovirus (cVDPV), immunodeficiency-related vaccine-derived poliovirus (iVDPV), and ambiguous vaccine-derived poliovirus (aVDPV). 

 

cVDPV is associated with community outbreaks, iVDPV is found in individuals with primary immunodeficiencies, and aVDPV is of uncertain epidemiological significance.

Key risk factors for cVDPV emergence: 

 

  • Development of immunity gaps (due to low OPV coverage)
  • Prior elimination of WPV types
    – Low routine immunization coverage with trivalent OPV
  • Insensitive AFP surveillance

 

Diagnosis: Real time Reverse transcription and PCR nucleic acid amplification

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. cVDPV is known to cause outbreaks in under-immunized communities.

 

Option B. iVDPV can cause disease in individuals with immunodeficiencies.

 

Option C. aVDPV is a category used when the source of the virus is unknown; it can potentially be involved in outbreaks.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref: Journal: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p479, 2/e p498, Vaccine-Derived Polioviruses. JID 2014:210 (Suppl 1) S283

questions.text: A 25-year-old medical volunteer working in a polio-endemic region is tasked with educating local communities about the disease. Which of the following countries is she most likely to be in, given the current status of polio transmission as of the latest global health reports?
questions.solution:
Ans. D). Afghanistan

 

Option D:

 

As of the latest reports prior to my last update in April 2023, polio was still endemic in two countries: Pakistan and Afghanistan. Given the options, Afghanistan is a correct choice.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. India was declared polio-free by the WHO in 2014.

 

Option B. Srilanka - The last confirmed case of polio in Sri Lanka was in 1993.

 

Option C. Brazil is not a polio-endemic country and has been polio-free since 1999.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Polio still remains endemic in two countries Afghanistan and Pakistan. 

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p480, 2/e p499, www.cdc.gov/polio

choices.text: Most cases of poliomyelitis result in spastic paralysis.
Bulbar involvement is common in poliomyelitis and can lead to respiratory compromise.
Intramuscular injections are recommended in the acute phase of poliomyelitis to prevent paralysis.
Polio vaccine is contraindicated in children older than 3 years.

questions.text: A pediatrician is reviewing the case of a 3-year-old boy with acute onset of fever and asymmetric flaccid paralysis of the right leg. There is no sensory loss, and deep tendon reflexes are diminished in the affected limb. Which of the following is a true statement regarding the presentation and characteristics of poliomyelitis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Bulbar involvement is common in poliomyelitis and can lead to respiratory compromise.

 

Option B:

 

Poliomyelitis often affects the anterior horn cells of the spinal cord, leading to flaccid paralysis, not spastic paralysis. Bulbar polio can affect the medulla oblongata and result in life-threatening complications like respiratory compromise.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Poliomyelitis typically results in flaccid paralysis due to anterior horn cell damage.

 

Option C. Intramuscular injections are not recommended in acute poliomyelitis because they can exacerbate muscle damage.

 

Option D. The polio vaccine is part of the routine immunization schedule and is not contraindicated based solely on age.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In poliomyelitis, bulbar involvement is a significant concern, as it leads to respiratory compromise due to the paralysis of muscles involved in breathing and swallowing

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p477, 2/e p497-498

questions.text:
A 3-year-old child presents with fever, oral lesions, and a rash on the hands and feet. The oral lesions are painful, with a red base and a small blister on top. The rash on the hands and feet consists of small, red, flat lesions. 

 

 

Which virus is the most likely cause of this clinical presentation?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Coxsackie A virus

 

Option A:

 

Coxsackie A virus is the most likely cause of the child's symptoms, which are characteristic of hand, foot, and mouth disease. This illness typically presents with a vesicular rash on the hands, feet, and oral mucosa, and Coxsackie A virus (particularly serotypes A16 and A6) is a common etiological agent.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Pox virus causes molluscum contagiosum and smallpox, which present differently.

 

Option C. Herpes simplex type 1 virus causes oral herpes, which typically does not present with a rash on the hands and feet.

 

Option D. Togavirus, which includes Rubella virus, does not cause these specific symptoms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Coxsackie A virus is the common cause of Hand, Foot, and Mouth Disease in young children, characterized by fever, oral lesions, and a rash on the hands and feet.

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Med Microbiology 1e/p480

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT typically caused by Coxsackie 'A' virus?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hepatitis

 

Option C:

 

Coxsackie 'A' virus does not typically cause hepatitis. This virus is known to cause aseptic meningitis, conjunctivitis, and hand-foot-mouth disease, among other syndromes.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Aseptic meningitis can be caused by Coxsackie 'A' virus.

 

Option B. Conjunctivitis can be part of the systemic symptoms caused by Coxsackie 'A' virus.

 

Option D. Hand-foot-mouth disease is classically caused by Coxsackie 'A' virus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The range of illnesses caused by Coxsackie 'A' virus - aseptic meningitis, conjunctivitis, and hand-foot-mouth disease.

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Med. Microbiology 2/e p500, Jawetz 24/e Ch. 36; Greenwood 16/e p.459

questions.text: A 6-year-old child presents to the emergency department with a high-grade fever, headache, and altered mental status. The mother also reports that the child has been experiencing vomiting and neck stiffness. A lumbar puncture is performed, showing an increase in white blood cells with a lymphocytic predominance. Which of the following viruses is the most common cause of viral meningoencephalitis in children?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Enteroviruses

 

Option B:

 

Enteroviruses are the most common cause of aseptic meningitis and meningoencephalitis in children, particularly during summer and fall. The clinical presentation and cerebrospinal fluid profile are suggestive of viral meningoencephalitis, which is most frequently caused by enteroviruses.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Arboviruses can cause meningoencephalitis but are less common than enteroviruses.

 

Option C. Herpes viruses, particularly HSV-1, can cause encephalitis, often with a more severe presentation and focal findings on imaging.

 

Option D. Mumps viruses can cause meningoencephalitis but have become less common due to vaccination.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Enteroviruses is the most common etiologic agent for viral meningoencephalitis in children

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p480-81, 2/e p500-501

questions.text: A 4-year-old child presents with high fever, sore throat, and difficulty swallowing. On examination, there are small vesicular lesions with erythematous halos on the oropharyngeal mucosa and tonsillar pillars. Which of the following is the most likely cause of herpangina in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Coxsackie A

 

Option C:

 

Herpangina is typically caused by Coxsackie A virus, serotypes 1-6,8,10 and is characterized by the sudden onset of fever, sore throat, and vesicular lesions on the oropharyngeal mucosa, often with a red border.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. HSV typically causes gingivostomatitis or herpes labialis, not herpangina.

 

Option B. HIV does not cause herpangina.

 

Option D. Coxsackie B is more commonly associated with myocarditis and pleurodynia, not herpangina.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Coxsackie A virus is the causative agent of herpangina

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p480-81, 2/e p500-501

questions.text: A pediatrician is reviewing the case of an infant presenting with fever, irritability, and signs of cardiac distress. Echocardiography reveals evidence of myocarditis. Which of the following viruses is the most common cause of infantile pericarditis and myocarditis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Coxsackie B

 

Option A:

 

Coxsackie B virus is the most common viral cause of myocarditis and pericarditis in infants and children. It can lead to symptoms of heart failure and cardiac distress.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Coxsackie A is more commonly associated with herpangina and hand, foot, and mouth disease.

 

Option C. Polio virus does not typically cause myocarditis.

 

Option D. Adenovirus can cause myocarditis but is less common than Coxsackie B virus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Coxsackie B virus being the most common viral cause of myocarditis and pericarditis in pediatric patients. 

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p480-81, 2/e p500-501

questions.text: An outbreak of acute hemorrhagic conjunctivitis has been reported in a local school. Public health officials are trying to identify the causative agent. Which enterovirus serotype is most commonly associated with acute hemorrhagic conjunctivitis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Serotype 70

 

Option C:

 

Enterovirus serotype 70 is one of the main causes of acute hemorrhagic conjunctivitis, which is a highly contagious eye infection that can cause eye pain, redness, swelling, and subconjunctival hemorrhage.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Serotype 68 is not typically associated with acute hemorrhagic conjunctivitis.

 

Option B. Serotype 69 has not been commonly linked to acute hemorrhagic conjunctivitis.

 

Option D. Serotype 71 is associated with hand, foot, and mouth disease and herpangina, not typically with acute hemorrhagic conjunctivitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Enterovirus serotype 70 as a causative agent of acute hemorrhagic conjunctivitis during outbreaks of the disease

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p480-81, 2/e p500-501

questions.text: A 2-year-old child presents with fever, irritability, and a history of several episodes of diarrhea. On examination, the child has a maculopapular rash on the hands and feet and small ulcers in the mouth. The mother reports that the child has been in close contact with other children with similar symptoms. Which of the following is the primary disease caused by the most likely virus in this case?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Aseptic meningitis

 

Option B:

 

The childs symptoms are classic for Hand, Foot, and Mouth Disease (HFMD):

Fever, irritability, oral ulcers, and maculopapular or vesicular rash on hands and feet

Common in young children with recent contact exposure

The most common cause is Coxsackievirus A16, a member of the Enterovirus genus (along with EV71, Coxsackie A & B).


While HFMD itself is usually mild and self-limiting, Enteroviruses especially Coxsackie A & B and EV71 are also the leading viral cause of aseptic meningitis, particularly in children.
 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Hepatitis is more commonly associated with hepatitis viruses.

 

Option C. Conjunctivitis is not the primary disease caused by Coxsackie A virus associated with the symptoms described.

 

Option D. Myocarditis: Coxsackie B viruses are more associated with myocarditis, but this is not the main manifestation in the scenario described.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Coxsackie A virus is the primary etiological agent of hand, foot, and mouth disease in children.

 

Ref: Apurba Sastrys Essentials of Med. Microbiology 2/e p500

choices.text: All of the above are correct associations

questions.text: A public health worker is investigating an outbreak of viral illnesses in a small community. The symptoms range from herpangina in children to acute hemorrhagic conjunctivitis in adults. The worker needs to identify the viruses responsible for these illnesses to guide the community health response. Which of the following associations between viruses and diseases is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) All of the above are correct associations

 

Explanation:

 

Coxsackie A virus is commonly associated with herpangina, characterized by fever, sore throat, and small vesicular lesions in the oropharynx. 

 

Enterovirus 70 is known to cause acute hemorrhagic conjunctivitis, presenting with eye redness, pain, and subconjunctival hemorrhage. 

 

Coxsackie B virus is a frequent cause of myocarditis, which can present with symptoms of heart failure in infants and children.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recognize the specific associations between viruses and the diseases they cause: Coxsackie A virus with herpangina, Enterovirus 70 with acute hemorrhagic conjunctivitis, and Coxsackie B virus with myocarditis.

 

Ref: Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p481, 2/e p500-501

choices.text: Detection of rabies virus antigen in saliva using an enzyme immunoassay
Isolation of the rabies virus from serum
Detection of rabies virus RNA in saliva using reverse transcription-polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR)
Computed tomography (CT) scan of the brain

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents to the emergency department with a history of hydrophobia and aerophobia. He reports being bitten by a stray dog about a month ago. On examination, he appears anxious and has difficulty swallowing. His family reports episodes of agitation and confusion. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step to confirm the diagnosis of rabies?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Detection of rabies virus RNA in saliva using reverse transcription-polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR)

 

Option C:

 

The most accurate method to confirm rabies in a living patient is to detect rabies virus RNA in saliva using RT-PCR. This method is highly sensitive and specific and can provide results quickly, which is crucial for a disease like rabies that requires immediate intervention.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Detection of rabies virus antigen in saliva using an enzyme immunoassay can be used, but it is less sensitive than RT-PCR.

 

Option B. Isolation of the rabies virus from serum is not commonly done due to the low concentration of the virus in the blood and the invasive nature of the procedure.

 

Option D. A CT scan of the brain is not specific for rabies and cannot confirm the diagnosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rabies in a living patient - RT-PCR is the diagnostic test of choice due to its high sensitivity and specificity, especially in patients who present with hydrophobia and aerophobia after a dog bite. 

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Med Microbiology 1/e p499, 2/e p520

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman presents to the clinic with symptoms of acute gastroenteritis, including diarrhea and vomiting. She reports consuming shellfish at a local restaurant two days prior. Given the likely diagnosis of a viral gastroenteritis caused by shellfish ingestion, which of the following is the most common organism responsible for her condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Norovirus

 

Option C:

 

Norovirus is the most common cause of acute gastroenteritis associated with shellfish consumption. It is known for causing outbreaks, especially in situations where contaminated food is served, such as shellfish that have not been properly cooked.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Calicivirus - While noroviruses are a type of calicivirus, the term "calicivirus" is too broad and non-specific in this context.

 

Option B. Enterovirus type 40, 41 - These are typically not associated with shellfish consumption.

 

Option B. Rotavirus - While it causes gastroenteritis, it is more commonly associated with infections in children and is not typically linked to shellfish consumption.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Noroviruses may be the most common infectious agents of mild gastroenteritis in the community and affect all age groups. It accounts for the majority of adult outbreaks of Gastroenteritis associated with Shellfish and salad ingredients.

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p526, 2/e p547-548, Harrison 19/e p1286, 20/e p1467

questions.text: A 37-year-old man presents with a sudden onset of respiratory distress, fever, and cough. He has recently returned from a business trip to a region experiencing an outbreak of a severe respiratory illness. Chest X-ray shows bilateral infiltrates, consistent with acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS). Which of the following viruses is most likely responsible for his condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Coronavirus

 

Option B:

 

Given the patient's travel history to a region with an outbreak of severe respiratory illness and the presentation of ARDS, the most likely cause is a coronavirus. Coronaviruses, including SARS-CoV and MERS-CoV, are known to cause severe respiratory illnesses that can lead to ARDS.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. RSV - While RSV can cause severe respiratory illness, especially in infants and the elderly, it is less likely to be associated with travel-related outbreaks of severe respiratory illness.

 

Option C. Influenza virus - Influenza can cause severe respiratory illness, but the context of a recent outbreak in the patient's travel history points more towards coronavirus.

 

Option D. Measles virus - Measles can cause severe respiratory symptoms but is less likely to cause ARDS in the described scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The association between recent travel to outbreak areas and the development of severe respiratory symptoms is critical in identifying potential cases of coronavirus infections, which can lead to conditions like ARDS.

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p521, 2/e p542-543
